column2: During each block's middle 5 weeks of L4 commissioning, only one crew is required on-site. The alternate crew is on "standby" - available for mobilization but not actively deployed. This provides:
- Schedule flexibility if a block experiences delays or deficiencies requiring additional resources
- Backup capacity during peak overlap periods (Oct-Dec when 2-3 blocks may need support)
- Resource availability for punch list resolution or vendor support issues
- Holiday coverage and crew rotation capability. Standby crews may perform: training, procedure development, vendor coordination calls, equipment procurement, or support other projects.

column2: - Thanksgiving week (Nov 27-28): Plan for 2-3 day shutdown. Ensure no critical testing scheduled this week.
- Christmas week (Dec 25): Plan for 3-4 day shutdown. Block 4 should be substantially complete before Dec 23.
- New Year's week (Jan 1): Reduced crew or delayed startup of critical activities until Jan 5.
- Build 1 additional week of float into Blocks 4 and 5 schedules to account for holiday disruptions.

column9: Both crews × 12 weeks × 500 hrs/week = 12,000 site hours. Mgmt: 12 weeks × 75 hrs/week = 900 hours.

column2: 1. Two fully redundant 10-person crews provide schedule flexibility and risk mitigation
2. Crews alternate as primary for data hall blocks (Crew A: Blocks 1/3/5; Crew B: Blocks 2/4/6)
3. Both crews active during: Switchyard phase (12 weeks) and block transition weeks (2 weeks per block)
4. Single crew adequate for middle 3 weeks of each block's L4 phase - alternate crew on standby
5. Cx Manager provides continuous program oversight across all blocks (hybrid/remote full-time)
6. Documentation Coordinator supports all blocks centrally (hybrid/remote 50% time)
7. Standby crews available for: punch list support
8. Holiday impacts Blocks 4 and 5 significantly (Thanksgiving through New Year's) - additional float recommended
9. Network Room commissioning occurs concurrently with Block 1-2 as L1-3 oversight activity
10. Schedule assumes GC substantial completion and successful L3 handoff per block start date

column4: Standby crew can mobilize to accelerate catch-up, or support parallel activities in other blocks
Standby crew provides surge capacity for deficiency resolution and retesting
Dual crews allow continued progress on non-vendor-dependent systems
Indoor activities can proceed; standby crew provides makeup capacity
Crew rotation allows skeleton crew coverage during holidays, or planned shutdowns
Redundant expertise across both crews mitigates single-person dependencies
Two full crews can simultaneously address issues in adjacent blocks during overlap periods

column2: The dual crew model provides significant schedule risk mitigation, particularly during the Oct-Dec peak period when multiple blocks are active and holidays impact productivity. The 24% increase in total program cost (20 people vs 10) is justified by schedule certainty and flexibility.
